_error.usage: Single item object for collection of _errors array

_errors.usage: Stores errors encountered during event schema validation

accesses.usage: List of accesses for an account, typically recorded in the windows event logs as "Accesses"

accessgroup.usage: Access group, tupically for authorization purposes

accessmask.usage: A 32-bit value that specifies the rights that are allowed or denied in an access control entry (ACE).

accountdomain.usage: accountdomain, used in accountname/accountdomain pairs typically found in authentication events from windows and other log types

accountid.usage: any one specific account identifier, see also userid for specific users

accountname.usage: accountname, used in accountname/accountdomain pairs typically found in authentication events from windows and other log types

ackduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to acknowledge

acktimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was acknowledged

aclname.usage: Access Control List name, typically referring to router ACLs

aclnumber.usage: Access Control List number, typcially referring to router ACLs

acquire_attempt_count.usage: In HIP events, the count of the acquire attempts

acquired_at_time.usage: In HIP events, date/time that something was acknowledged

acquired_by.usage: In HIP events, a descriptive name for the ownership

action.usage: Action in the generic sense, typically representing action taken as a result of an event (allow,drop,quarantine,etc)

activity.usage: Any activity name, typically found in windows event logs as activity

activityid.usage: Any activity identifier, typically found in windows event logs as activity ID

actor.usage: The user or service principal that performed the action

addl.usage: in bro logs, additional responses for the query

agent.usage: Referencing an agent by name, typically when unique from hostname or similar, see also agentid

agentversion.usage: Version of the agent named in the log

alertdomain.usage: Used to represent the domain of a generated alert for FireEye and other devices

alerted.usage: In HIP events, field for alerted

alerturi.usage: Used to represent the URI of a generated alert for FireEye and other devices

alerturl.usage: Used to represent the URL of a generated alert for FireEye and other devices

analyzer.usage: General purpose field for an analyzer

apipv4.usage: IPv4 address of the Access Point

apipv6.usage: IPv6 address of the Access Point

apname.usage: Access Point name, typically referred as AP in WLAN configurations and logs

appcategory.usage: Application category for application monitoring in Checkpoint logs & other.

appid.usage: Application ID for application monitoring within Checkpoint logs & other.

application.usage: General purpose field for representing an application name

apppath.usage: Path where the application can be found in the system

appproperties.usage: Designates application properties for Checkpoint & other logs.

args.usage: arguments supplied to a command or operation

attachment.usage: Attachment, typically observed as a filename attached to an email or IM communication

attack.usage: Attack name, typically observed in the firewall or proxy logs

attemptingAcquire.usage: In HIP events, a field to hold for attempting acquire

audititemid.usage: audititemid used as an identifier to audit items

auth.usage: in bro logs, authoritatice responses for the query

authmethod.usage: The method of authentication used, e.g. local, domain, LDAP. Could also include network authmethods e.g. LANMAN, NTLMv1, NTLMv2, kerberos, etc

authoritativeanswer.usage: The Authoritative Answer bit for response messages specifies that the responding name server is an authority for the domain name in the question section.

ax_malicious_alerts.usage: In HIP events, the ax malicious alerts

ax_score.usage: In HIP events, score as defined by the log source, typically referring to the current ax score

bay.usage: used to capture a bay, typically referring to infrastructure equipment.

behavior.usage: General purpose field for representing behavior

binary_can_sleep.usage: In HIP events, binary can sleep

binary_languages.usage: In HIP events,a field for binary languages

binarystate.usage: The state of a value in boolean

bytes.usage: Bytes in the generic sense, often used when direction is unknown. In Bro file logs this is total number of bytes that are supposed to comprise the full file.

bytespersec.usage: Total number of bytes per second

cachetype.usage: a type of chache, e.g. ARP cache or other

cacheval.usage: a value found in some type of cache, see also cachetype

callingdomain.usage: Authentication domain of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as calling domain

callinglogonid.usage: Windows login id of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as caller logon id

callingsrcip.usage: source IP of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as calling address

callingsrcipv6.usage: Source IPv6 of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as "Calling Address"

callinguid.usage: User ID of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as calling id

callingusername.usage: Username of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as calling username

callingusersecurityid.usage: Unique, immutable identifier of a remote calling identity, typically observed in windows event logs as caller user

capture_password.usage: in bro logs, determines if the password will be captured for this request

category.usage: General purpose field for Category, typcially identifies a product specific category of event, alert, or activity

cc.usage: General purpose field for representing cc, with respect to origin. Typically used in email, IM, etc.

cert_chain.usage: in bro logs, chain of certificates offered by the server to validate its complete signing chain

cert_chain_fuids.usage: in bro logs, an ordered vector of all certicate file unique id's for the certificates offered by the server

cert_errors.usage: A field for representing Certificate errors

cert_permanent.usage: in bro logs, indicates if the provided certificate or cert chain is permanent or temporary

cert_type.usage: in bro logs, if the connection is being encrypted with native rdp encryption, this is the type of cert being used

certsubject.usage: Certificate subject, in Bro ssl logs this is the 'subject' field.

charencoding.usage: character encoding being used, e.g. ASCII, UNCODE, etc.

city.usage: The full name of the city, used for geolocation

classid.usage: Class ID reserved for event collection purposes only

client.usage: in bro logs, the client's version string

client_cert_chain.usage: in bro logs, chain of certificates offered by the client to validate its complete signing chain

client_cert_chain_fuids.usage: in bro logs, an ordered vector of all certicate file unique id's for the certificates offered by the client

client_key_exchange_seen.usage: in bro logs, flag to indicate if we saw a client key exchange message sent by the client.

client_ticket_empty_session_seen.usage: in bro logs, flag to indicate if we saw a non-empty session ticket being sent by the client using an empty session id

client_uuid.usage: A universally unique client identifier is an identifier standard used in software construction

clientissuersubject.usage: Client Issuer certificate subject, in Bro ssl logs, this is the subject of the signer of the X.509 certificate offered by the client.

clientsubject.usage: Client certificate subject, in Bro ssl logs, this is the subject of the X.509 certificate offered by the client.

closeduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to close

closetime.usage: date/time that something was closed, typically referring to workflow

closetimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was closed, typically referring to workflow

cmdarg.usage: in bro logs, command that is currently waiting for response

cnchost.usage: Used for identifying CNC (Command and Control) Host servers, typically malicious in nature.

cncipv4.usage: Used for identifying CNC (Command and Control) Host server communication IP version 4 addresses. These could be either ingress or egress.

cncport.usage: Used for identifying CNC (Command and Control) Host server communication ports. These could be either ingress or egress.

compile_time.usage: The date/time when something was compiled

compression_alg.usage: in bro logs, the compression algorithm in use

confidence.usage: General purpose field used to capture confidence level

connstate.usage: Connection state, found in Bro conn logs, identifies the state of a connection via defined connstate codes, ref: bro documentation for the latest definitions.

containduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to contain

containtime.usage: date/time that something was contained, typically referring to host containment during an IR activity

containtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was contained, typically referring to host containment during an IR activity

content.usage: content type, referring to HTTP content-type

context_tags.usage: Context tags added by decoration or other services

count.usage: General purpose field used for capturing a count of any value

count_updated_at_time.usage: In HIP events, the date/time when count was updated

country.usage: The full name of the country, used for geolocation

countrycode.usage: The country code, used for geolocation

createdtime.usage: date/time that something was created or instantiated, implies there are follow on stamps

createdtimeutc.usage: UTC  date/time that something was created or instantiated, implies there are follow on stamps

creatorprocessid.usage: any one specific creator process identifier

current_status.usage: In HIP events, the current status

current_status_txt.usage: In HIP events, the current status text

curve.usage: in bro logs, elliptic curve the server chose when using ecdh?/cdhe

cveid.usage: Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures identifier, ref http://cve.mitre.org/cve/identifiers/index.html

cwd.usage: in bro logs, current working directory that this session is in

data_channel.usage: in bro logs, expected ftp data channel

day.usage: General purpose field for day values

dbinstance.usage: General purpose field for representing a database instance

dbname.usage: General purpose field for representing a database name

dbtable.usage: General purpose field for representing a database table

dcid.usage: Delivery Connection ID used in Ironport E-mail. Each recipient to the same domain gets the same DCID, otherwise each recipient gets a different one.

defgw.usage: Default gateway, typically referenced in network events

depth.usage: General purpose field for representing the depth of something, e.g. 32bytes,

description.usage: General purpose field used to capture an event description, often free formed text messages unable to be further parsed

desktop_height.usage: in bro logs, desktop height of client machine

desktop_width.usage: in bro logs, desktop width of client machine

detect_ruleids.usage: In Detection, the rule id's of the matching rule(s)

detect_rulematch.usage: In Detection, an object containing the rule id, name, severity, confidence and tags

detect_rulematches.usage: In Detection, an array containing multiple "detect_rulematch" objects

detect_rulenames.usage: In Detection, an array containing multiple rule names

detectedtime.usage: date/time that the detection took place

detectedtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that the detection took place

devicename.usage: a devicename, e.g. removable media device name.  See also hostname

devicetype.usage: a device type, typically reserved for categories of devices, see also deviceid

direction.usage: Used to specify logical flow or direction, inbound/outbound, etc.

disabled_aids.usage: in bro logs, disabled analyzer id's

disk.usage: the name of a disk, typically a physical disk, see also volume

disposition.usage: The final result condition that something ended in (success, failure, etc) Not to be confused with status

distance.usage: In Analytics events, the distance between two events in miles

domain.usage: Domain from which an identity resides, typically an Active Directory domain, LDAP domain, Kerberos realm, etc.

done.usage: in bro logs, status of rdp connections done if t

driver.usage: Name of the driver installed, modified or deleted. Typically observed in windows event logs as "Driver"

dropped.usage: In Bro notice logs, the dropped field indicates a T/F bool.

dstcountry.usage: The full name of the destination country, when orientation is known, used for geolocation

dstcountrycode.usage: The destination counrty code, when source/dest is known, used for geolocation

dsthost.usage: hostname of the destination manchine, when direction is known and/or relevant, will typically resolve to dstip or dstipv6

dstmac.usage: MAC address of the destination when direction is known

dstnatrule.usage: JunOS destination address NAT flow rule name

dstserver.usage: IPv4 address of the destination server in a DHCP connection

dstzone.usage: Destination zone, when direction is known and/or relevant, typically reserved for network or firewall events specifying a logical  zone within the event

dynamic_indicators.usage: In HIP events, the dynamic indicators

enc_appdata_bytes.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

enc_appdata_packages.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

encodedmsg.usage: the encoded version of the message or string

encryption_level.usage: in bro logs, encryption level of the connection

endtime.usage: date/time that something ended, typically referring to connection events or events with a definitive start and end

endtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something ended, typically referring to connection events or events with a definitive start and end

enriched.usage: In HIP events, whether the information is enriched

enrichment_error.usage: In HIP events, a field for the encountered enrichment error

enrichment_start.usage: In HIP events, The date/time of enrichment start

enrichment_status_txt.usage: In HIP events, the enrichment status text - Enrichment Started | MCUBE Whitelist Lookup | MCUBE Whitelist Pending Result | MCUBE Whitelist Lookup Done | Start Auto Tagging | Done Auto Tagging | Checking File Owner | File Owner Not Trusted | Satori Lookup Start | Satori Reported Unknown | File Acquire Job Queued | File Acquire Download Complete | Downloading Acquired File | File Acquire Complete | Submit to Satori | Satori Returned Sample | Polling Satori Status | Polling Satori Complete | Satori Done | Nucleus Returned Data | Nucleus Done | Ip/Domain Enrichment Requested

errorcode.usage: Specific field reserved for explicit interger error codes

errormessage.usage: Specific field reserved for error code text strings

escalateduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to escalate

escalatetime.usage: date/time that something was escalated, typically referring to workflow

escalatetimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was escalated, typically referring to workflow

established.usage: in bro logs, flag to indicate if this ssl session has been established successfully or aborted

eventid.usage: General purpose field used to capture any one specific event identifier

eventlog.usage: name of the specific event log that the event came from

eventname.usage: Description of the event included in the CEF log header

eventreceivedtime.usage: date/time in which the event was received

eventtime.usage: date/time that the actual event took place, as found in the payload of the message.

eventtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that the actual event took place, as found in the payload of the message.

eventtype.usage: Type of event, as often used in Windows events.

evil_flag.usage: In HIP events, a flag whether the event is evil

evil_indicators.usage: In HIP events, identify a set of evil indicators of various attributes.

exceptionlvl.usage: To display an excpetional level integer as from a service like MS Exchange ActiveSync

exceptionmsg.usage: To display an exception message for a service such as MS Exchange ActiveSync

exceptiontype.usage: The type of exception given by an application such as MS Exchange ActiveSync.

expirationtime.usage: date/time that something will or has expired

expirationtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something will or has expired

extendedproperties.usage: Generic object for collecting extended properties and their values.

extnatip.usage: External NAT IP address, used in NAT logs

extnatipv6.usage: External NAT IPv6 address, used in NAT logs

extracted.usage: In Bro logs, if the file extraction successfully extracted the file from the stream.

facility.usage: Syslog facility. Used to specify the type of program that is logging the message, typically observed in unix logs

family.usage: General purpose field used to specify a family name or logical grouping, typically one or more malware families.

file_accessed_time.usage: General purpose date/time field for file access time

file_created_time.usage: General purpose date/time field for file creation

file_enrichment_status.usage: In HIP events, the file enrichment status

file_mime_type.usage: Specifically distinguising a specific file MIMEtype as observed in a message

file_modified_time.usage: General purpose date/time field for file modification

file_owner.usage: General purpose field for representing a file owner.

file_signed.usage: In HIP events, whether the file was signed or not

filedesc.usage: In Bro notice logs, file_desc is a file description.

filename.usage: General purpose field for representing a file name, may or may not include the entire file path preceding the file name.

filepath.usage: General purpose field for representing a file path

filepermission.usage: General purpose field for representing file permission

filetype.usage: The type of file, as referenced by the log source

filter.usage: a specific filter, as defined by the log source

fingerprint.usage: A SSL or TLS fingerprint, as used in bro_ssl logs.

firstseen.usage: date/time that something was first seen, typically referring to malware indicators or IR related events.

firstseenutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was first seen, typically referring to malware indicators or IR related events.

flagtype.usage: General purpose field for representing a flag name

flagval.usage: General purpose field for representing a flag value

force_log.usage: in bro logs, indicates that this software being detected should definitely be sent onward to the logging framework

foreigninterface.usage: Foreign interface identifier, typically reserved for network or firewall events specifying interface orientation

fqdn_nucleus_summary.usage: In HIP events, the fqdn nucleus summary

from.usage: General purpose field for representing from, with respect to origin. Typically used in email, IM, etc.

function.usage: Refered to a function in a program source code.

fwdipv4.usage: IPv4 forwarding address typically used in firewall devices

fwdipv6.usage: IPv6 forwarding address typically used in firewall devices

group.usage: General purpose field for representing a group, typically a AD or LDAP group, but could be the name of any logical grouping.

groupdomain.usage: Authentication domain of a group, typically observed in windows event logs as "Group Domain"

groupsecurityid.usage: Unique, immutable identifier of a Windows user group.

gwipv4.usage: IPv4 address of the gateway not set as default, typically referenced in network events

gwipv6.usage: IPv6 address of the gateway not set as default, typically referenced in network events

handleid.usage: any one specific handle identifier, referring to process handle IDs.

hasMTAReport.usage: In HIP events, whether the log has a message/mail transfer agent(MTA) report

has_cert_table.usage: in bro logs, true if file has attribute certificate table

has_debug_data.usage: in bro logs, true if file has debug data

has_export_table.usage: in bro logs, true if file has export table

has_import_table.usage: in bro logs, true if file has import table

hash.usage: General purpose field for storing any type of message digest hash value

heartbleed_detected.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

hierarchy.usage: A description of how and where the requested object was fetched

history.usage: History, found in Bro conn logs, records the state history of connections as a string of letters. Ref: bro documentation for the latest definitions.

host_key.usage: in bro logs, the server's key fingerprint

host_key_alg.usage: in bro logs, the server host key's algorithm

hostname.usage: hostname, used whenever source or dest is unclear or unknown.

hour.usage: General purpose field for hour values

httpbody.usage: Indicator of client body based SQL injection attack. This is typically the body content of a POST request.

icid.usage: Injection Connection ID used in Ironport E-mail. ICID assigned when a remote host connects to the appliance.

impact.usage: General purpose field used to capture impact level

info.usage: Supplemental info for a given event that is optional or adding supplimental context, typically not well delimited for fine parsing

infocode.usage: Informational message from Bro http logs, containing the last seen 1xx informational reply code returned by the server.

infomsg.usage: Informational message from Bro http logs, containing the last seen 1xx informational reply message returned by the server.

inreplyto.usage: RFC 4021 Header information, for mail in reply to header designations

instance_tags.usage: AWS EC2 instance tags as key-value pair

integritylevel.usage: Representation of the trustworthiness of running application processes and objects, such as files created by the application

intelwhitelisted.usage: Intel-supplied boolean marking if the synthetic intel hit event has a whitelisted observable.

intel_context.usage: Intel-supplied variable context for intel events.

intel_context_unavailable.usage: Intel supplied variable set to true if the hit synthetic event does NOT have observable context

intel_match_observable.usage: Intel supplied list variable representing a single field and value within a match

intel_matches.usage: Intel supplied variable representing a list of field and value pairs in a match

intelalertmessage.usage: Analyst-supplied message for indicator that will show in the UI

intelalertnotes.usage: Anaylist-supplied notes if even applicable to support the alert message.

intelmalwarefamily.usage: In tier1 we typically know a family of malware/activity

intelmatchclass.usage: The class of the raw event in the match, for example 'cisco_firewall'

intelmatchfield.usage: Custom field used by Mandiant intel matching service to indicate the field that the intel indicator matched against.

intelmatchtime.usage: Custom field used by Mandiant intel matching service to indicate the date/time the indicator was matched to the event.

intelmatchvalue.usage: Custom field used by Mandiant intel matching service showing the indicator that was searched for.

intelmeta_cbid.usage: For intel, comm broker ID, 64 bit hex representation (derived from comm broker x509 certificate serial number and issuer hash)

intelmeta_mid.usage: For intel, message ID, 64 bit hex representation (monotonically ascend for a given comm broker)

intelscore.usage: This is the score applied to all indicators which will carry over to all accompanying matches

inteltype.usage: Custom field used by FireEye Intel matching service to indicate the type of intel indicator was matched to the event

inteluuid.usage: Unique identifier generated for each match

interface.usage: Logical or physical network interface used for communications (eth0, eth1, etc) when orientation is unknown

interfaceid.usage: Unique identifier assigned to a logical or physical network interface

intnatip.usage: Internal NAT IP address, used in NAT logs

iocname.usage: The name of the indicator of compromise

iocnames.usage: The name of the indicator of compromise

ip_nucleus_summary.usage: In HIP events, the ip nucleus summary

ipv4.usage: General purpose field for representing an IPv4 address, only used when source or dest is unclear or unknown.

ipv6.usage: General purpose field for representing an IPv6 address, only used when source or dest is unclear or unknown.

is_64bit.usage: in bro logs, true if file is 64-bit executable

is_exe.usage: in bro logs, true if file is executable

is_malware.usage: Whether something is a malware or not

isacquired.usage: In HIP events, whether the system was acquired or not

isorig.usage: In Bro logs, if the source of this file is a network connection, this field indicates if the file is being sent by the originator of the connection or the responder.

issuer.usage: General purpose field for representing an issuer, e.g. Certificate Issuer

issuersubject.usage: Issuer certificate subject, in Bro ssl logs, this is the subject of the signer of the X.509 certificate offered by the server.

issuetime.usage: date/time that something was issued, or becomes active, typically a certificate.

issuetimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was issued, or becomes active, typically a certificate.

job.usage: Any job name, typically found in windows event logs as job

jobid.usage: Any job identifier, typically found in windows event logs as job ID

kex_alg.usage: in bro logs, the key exchange algorithm in use

keypair.usage: AWS EC2 instance key pair name

keywords.usage: Hexadecimal value used to group events based on the usage of the events. Typically found on windows event logs

language.usage: To define a language within a logsource.

last_auth_requested.usage: in bro logs, last auth requested

last_originator_heartbeat_request_size.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

lastaccessedtime.usage: date/time that an object was last accessed

lastaccessedtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that an object was last accessed

lastalertid.usage: In Bro ssl logs, the last_alert field is the last alert that was seen during the connection

lastmodifiedtime.usage: date/time that an object was last modified

lastmodifiedtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that an object was last modified

lastscannedtime.usage: date/time that something was last scanned, typically used for vulnerability, AV, or other malware detection technologies

lastscannedtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was last scanned, typically used for vulnerability, AV, or other malware detection technologies

lastseen.usage: date/time that something was last seen, typically referring to malware indicators or IR related events.

lastseenutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was last seen, typically referring to malware indicators or IR related events.

length.usage: General purpose field for representing the length of something

level.usage: General purpose field for interger levels, such as level {1,2,3,} etc.

linenumber.usage: linenumber referencing the location in a page or file

local_resp.usage: in bro logs, true if connection is responded to locally, false if responded to remotely

localinterface.usage: Local interface identifier, typcially reserved for network or firewall events specifying interface orientation

localorig.usage: In Bro logs, if the source of this file is a network connection, this field indicates if the data originated from the local network or not as determined by the configured Site::local_nets.

logged.usage: in bro logs, whether this has already been logged and can be ignored

logonguid.usage: User ID of a login identity, typically observed in windows event logs as calling id

logonid.usage: Windows user login id's which are unique between reboots on the same computer. Used to positively correlate between logins and security event logs

logontype.usage: logon type referring to char string types (win32, ADVAPI, etc)

logontypeid.usage: Integer id that specifies type of windows logon (interactive/network/batch/etc)

mac.usage: General purpose field for MAC address, used whenever

mac_alg.usage: in bro logs, the signing (mac) algorithm in use

macoui.usage: The Organizationally Unique Identifier of a MAC address, ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address

mailfrom.usage: RFC 4021 Header information, for mailroom designations

malwarefamily.usage: Used to represent the family of a deteced malware

malwarename.usage: Used to represent the name of a detected malware

malwaretype.usage: Used to represent the type or FireEye assigned signature type of a detected malware

malwarevariant.usage: Used to represent the variant of a detected malware

mcube_list.usage: In HIP events, the mcube list

md5.usage: computed MD5 hash of an object

member.usage: Name of the group member added, modified or deleted. Typically observed in windows event logs as "Member Name"

memberdomain.usage: Name of the group member domain. Typically observed in windows event logs as member domain

membersecurityid.usage: Unique, immutable identifier of a group member. Typically observed in windows event logs as "Member ID"

meta_cbid.usage: comm broker ID, 64 bit representation (derived from comm broker x509 certificate serial number and issuer hash)

meta_i.usage: input ID, slash-delimited in the form of source/IP/port

meta_mid.usage: message ID, 64 bit representation (monotonically ascend for a given comm broker)

meta_odt.usage: original datetime (if rewritten) -- "-" means absent from original; specials are escaped using quoted-printable strategy

meta_ohn.usage: original hostname (if rewritten) -- "-" means absent from original; specials are escaped using quoted-printable strategy

meta_omh.usage: Meta original message header. The portion of the sent message that appears before what is placed in "rawmsg" within the UI.

meta_oml.usage: original (pre-RFC5424) length of message, 32 bit hex form (usually only 2 or 3 digits needed)

meta_opri.usage: original PRI (if rewritten) -- "-" means absent from original; specials are escaped using quoted-printable strategy

meta_rrm.usage: message rewrite method, "Q" for quoted-printable, "6" for base64

meta_rts.usage: Time at which event was received by the comm broker

meta_rule.usage: Meta rule identifier for pattern which log event has matched within PatternDB

meta_sip4.usage: IPv4 address of message source, 32 bit

meta_sip6.usage: IPv6 address of message source, RFC4291 form, hex digits only, with :: compaction

meta_sts.usage: stale time stamp, time when time was last sync'd, sent during time sync outage

meta_ts.usage: time stamp, 64 bit representation (microseconds since the Unix epoch, 1970-Jan-1 midnight UTC)

metaclass.usage: Meta-class of the event log being collected.

method.usage: General purpose field for representing method, see also httpmethod and authmethod

mid.usage: Message ID used in Ironport E-mail. Once connection established, each successful "mail from:" command creates a MID.

mimetype.usage: Specifically distinguising a specific MIMEtype as observed in a message

minute.usage: General purpose field for minute values

missingbytes.usage: In Bro logs, the number of bytes in the file stream that were completely missed during the process of analysis e.g. due to dropped packets.

mode.usage: General purpose field for representing the mode of something, as defined by the log source

modifiedproperties.usage: Generic object for collecting modified properties and their values.

month.usage: General purpose field for month values

msg.usage: General purpose field to capture some or all of the message, used only when field parsing is not desired.

msr_ruleids.usage: In Detection, the rule id's of multi-stage rule(s)

network.usage: Network segment, it can include the network prefix

next_protocol.usage: in bro logs, next protocol the server chose using the application layer next protocol extension if present

nick.usage: in bro logs, nickname given for the connection

node.usage: Reserved for specific references to a node, typically reserved for sensor nodes or similar uses explicitly calling out nodes

notice.usage: in bro logs, indicates if this weird was also turn into a notice

nuc_attribution_date.usage: In HIP events, the nuc attribution date/time

nuc_md5_attribution.usage: In HIP events, the nuc md5 attribution

number.usage: General purpose field for representing the order in which something is numbered in a sequence, e.g. partitionnumber=2, packetnumber=754

object.usage: Any object name, typically observed in the windows event logs as "Object"

objectserver.usage: Name of the system component handling the access request. Typically found on windows event logs

objecttype.usage: Any object type, typically observed in the windows event logs as "Object Type"

ocsp_response.usage: in bro logs, oscp response as a string

ocsp_status.usage: in bro logs, result of ocsp validation for this connection

offset.usage: General purpose field for representing the order in which something is offset, e.g. 4-bytes, 1024kb

old_period.usage: In Analytics beaconing events, the period in milliseconds

origin.usage: General purpose field for representing the origin

original_company_name.usage: In HIP events, field for original company name

original_description.usage: In HIP events, field for original description

original_file_name.usage: In HIP events, field for original file name

originationtime.usage: date/time that specifies the origination of something, implying when a transmission originated from A to B

originationtimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that specifies the origination of something, implying when a transmission originated from A to B

originator_heartbeats.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

os.usage: operating system, typically the major OS display name

overflowbytes.usage: In Bro logs, the number of not all-in-sequence bytes in the file stream that were delivered to file analyzers due to reassembly buffer overflow.

packet_segment.usage: in bro logs, a chunk of the payload that most likely resulted in the protocol violation

packets.usage: Generic packet count, typically only used when direction sent/rcvd is unknown

packettype.usage: Type of packet ex. SYN, FIN, R

page.usage: page, typtically referencing the existing page

parameters.usage: Generic object for collecting parameters and their values.

parentfileid.usage: any one specific parent file identifier. In Bro logs, this is the identifier associated with a container file from which the child (fileid) was extracted as part of the file analysis.

pargs.usage: parent arguments supplied to a command or operation

partition.usage: the name of a partition, see also volume

passive.usage: in bro logs, indicates if the session is in active or passive mode

password.usage: Password for a given username or account

peak.usage: Peak level as defined by the log source, typically referring to a peak level or percentage

pecreatedtime.usage: Date/time created as specified in the PE header of a PE file.

pecreatedtimeutc.usage: UTC Date/time created as specified in the PE header of a PE file.

peer.usage: a peer, typically in an authentication relationship

pending_commands.usage: in bro logs, queue for commands that have been sent but not yet responded to are tracked here

perchg.usage: Percent Changed as defined by the log source

period.usage: In Analytics beaconing events, the period in milliseconds

pid.usage: any one specific process ID, typically used for application PIDs

policy.usage: Typically the display name of the policy, see also policyid

portid.usage: any one specific portid or terminal port id

ppid.usage: any one specific parent process ID, typcially used for application PPIDs.

pprocess.usage: parent process or image, usually in Windows events.

pprocessguid.usage: parent process user ID, usually in Windows events.

prevscore.usage: previous score as defined by the log source, typcially referring to a score prior to some follow up activity or event

printer.usage: General purpose field for representing a printer object, physical or virtual

priority.usage: General purpose field used to capture a priority value

privileges.usage: privileges held or granted, typically as recorded in the windows event log

process.usage: a process, typically used for the full process name/description, see also pid and ppid

processguid.usage: Process user ID, usually in Windows events.

processpath.usage: Path where the process resides in the system

product.usage: a specific product, typically used when one log source contains multiple product types

profile.usage: General purpose field for representing a profile, as defined by the log source

program.usage: The name for a program, see also application

protocol.usage: protocol used in a session. Typcially http, ftp, smtp, etc.

protocolver.usage: representing a specific version of a protocol, used with 'protocol' field, e.g., TLSv1, TLSv2, TLSv3, etc.

protoid.usage: Numerical representation of a protocol (6=TCP, 17=UDP, 47=GRE, etc)

providerguid.usage: Globally unique identifier (GUID) of the provider that published the event. Typically found on windows event logs

proxied.usage: Proxied, from Bro http logs, contains all of the headers that may indicate if the request was proxied.

proxysrcipv4.usage: Designates the proxy source ip address.

proxystatuscode.usage: Numerical representation of a status from the proxy

query.usage: a query of some sort (DNS, Web, DB, etc)

queryclass.usage: the class of the query. (0,1,2,3, etc)

queryclassname.usage: A descriptive name for the class of query

querytype.usage: A QTYPE value specifying the type of query, typically 1,2,6,12, 28 etc.  Ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_DNS_record_types

querytypename.usage: A descriptive name for the type of query, A, NS, SOA, PTR, AAAA, etc.ref: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_DNS_record_types

rateavg.usage: Average rate as used in CISCO_ASA Threat Detection

rateid.usage: Configured rate being exceeded as used in CISCO_ASA Threat Detection

ratemax.usage: Maximum rate as used in CISCO_ASA Threat Detection.

rateval.usage: Current rate value as used in CISCO_ASA Threat Detection.

raw_facility.usage: The original facility as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_facilityid.usage: The original facility id as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_mid.usage: The original MSGID as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_odt.usage: The original date-time as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_omsg.usage: The full original message sent into the commbroker.

raw_pid.usage: The original PID as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_pri.usage: The original priority as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_sdata.usage: Structured data portion of non syslog-3164 logs as derived from the original message

raw_sev.usage: The original severity as extracted from the syslog header.

raw_sevid.usage: The original severity id as extracted from the syslog header.

rawmsg.usage: The entire raw message in it's original form as received from the origin.

rawmsghostipv4.usage: IPv4 address of the host sending the raw message.  In some cases, this may be a log relay or forwarder.

rawmsghostipv6.usage: IPv6 address of the host sending the raw message.  In some cases, this may be a log relay or forwarder.

rawmsghostname.usage: Hostname, when available, of the host sending the raw message.  In some cases, this may be a log relay or forwarder.

rawmsgid.usage: Globally unique identifier assigned to the rawmsg for reference

rawmsgtimeutc.usage: UTC Date and Time the raw message was received from the sending host durring event collection.

rawsrchostname.usage: The hostname or IP of the device that sent the message to the CB.

rcptto.usage: RFC 4021 Header information, for mail receipt to header designations

rcvdbodybytes.usage: In bro http logs, the response_body_len, is the actual uncompressed content size of the data transferred form the server.

rcvdbytes.usage: Total bytes received by dest from a source

rcvdfileid.usage: Received File identifier, found in Bro http logs as the resp_fuids value, indicates the file identifier of a file pertaining to a receiver.

rcvdipbytes.usage: In Bro logs, the resp_ip_bytes field that Number of IP level bytes that the responder sent (as seen on the wire, taken from the IP total_length header field).

rcvdmimetype.usage: Received MIME type, found in Bro http logs as the resp_mime_types value, indicates the mime type of a file pertaining to a receiver.

rcvdpackets.usage: number of packets received in the transaction

ready.usage: This value indicates if this request/response pair is ready to be logged.  Could be used for any BOOL ready status  (YES|NO) (True|False)

reason.usage: Reason in the generic sense, when a payload contains a more specific reason(s) for a given action, severity, or other field.

receptorhostid.usage: In HIP events, the receptor host id

recordid.usage: Used for parsing updates on Windows event logs. Allows for easier sorting of events in table view.

recursionavailable.usage: The Recursion Available bit in a response message indicates that the name server supports recursive queries.

recursiondesired.usage: The Recursion Desired bit in a request message indicates that the client wants recursive service for this query.

referenceid.usage: any one specific reference ID relating 2 or more things together.

referrer_domain.usage: The HTTP referrer field domain value

referrer_uri.usage: The HTTP referrer field which contains URI(path and query) values

region.usage: The state or providence, used for geolocation

regkey.usage: Registry key name, not the entire preceding regpath

regpath.usage: Basic registry path, could optionally include the reg key

regvalue.usage: Registry value contained within a key

rejected.usage: The DNS query was rejected by the server.  Could be used for any BOOL rejection status (YES|NO) (True|False)

replay_datasource.usage: Data source or file name/path from replayed logs

reply_code.usage: in bro logs, reply code from the server in response to the command

reply_msg.usage: in bro logs, reply message from the server in response to the command

replyto.usage: General purpose field for representing replyto, with respect to origin. Typically used in email, IM, etc.

reportduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to report

requestduration.usage: ammount of time in seconds that it took to request

requestid.usage: any one specific requestID, specifying the identifier of a given request. Typically authentication or query/response type of reqests.

requesttimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something was requested

responder_heartbeats.usage: in bro logs, present if heartbleed.bro is present

responsecode.usage: The response code value, typically in DNS response messages

responsecodename.usage: A descriptive name for the response code value

restrictedsidcount.usage: In Windows logs, the count of restricted security ID's

result.usage: The final result condition that something ended in (success, failure, etc) Not to be confused with status

resumed.usage: in bro logs, flag to indicate if the session was resumed reusing the key material exchanged in an earlier connection

rid.usage: Recipient ID used in Ironport E-mail. Each recipient (To: CC: or BCC:) will get a RID.

risk.usage: General purpose field used to capture any risk level when displayed by name (e.g. LOW,MED,HIGH,CRITICAL,etc) see also: risklevel

risklevel.usage: General purpose field used to capture any risk level when displayed by interger level (e.g. 0,1,2,3,etc) see also: risk

rt_version.usage: RT_VERSION hashes are a unique characteristic of Windows executable (PE) files. Found in fireeye_faf events.

rule.usage: Rule, typcally in the form of a rule name, signature name, title or brief message.

rulecat.usage: Rule or Singature Category, typically defined by the vendor and organized into one or more categories or logical groupings

ruleid.usage: Rule or Signature ID containing a unique ID for a given rule or signature, typically an INT but could contain a CHAR

satori_blacklist.usage: In HIP events, the satori blacklist

saw_query.usage: in bro logs, true if full dns query has been seen

saw_reply.usage: in bro logs, true if full dns reply has been seen

score.usage: score as defined by the log source, typically referring to the current score or most recent score

second.usage: General purpose field for second values

security_groups.usage: AWS EC2 security group names and ID’s concatenated with a colon

seenbytes.usage: In Bro logs, number of bytes provided to the file analysis engine for the file.

sentbodybytes.usage: In bro http logs, the request_body_len, is the actual uncompressed content size of the data transferred form the server.

sentbytes.usage: Total bytes sent from a source to a dest

sentfileid.usage: Sent File identifier, found in Bro http logs as the orig_fuids value, indicates the file identifier of a file pertaining to an orignator.

sentipbytes.usage: In Bro logs, the orig_ip_bytes field that Number of IP level bytes that the originator sent (as seen on the wire, taken from the IP total_length header field).

sentmimetype.usage: Sent MIME type, found in Bro http logs as the orig_mime_types value, indicates the mime type of a file pertaining to an orignator.

sentpackets.usage: number of packets sent in the transaction

serial.usage: Serial number field used to represent physical or virtual serial numbers

server.usage: Reserved for when srchost/dsthost does not apply, e.g. a central management server, proxy, router, etc. serving a nondirectional role.

server_depth.usage: in bro logs, current number of certificates seen from either side. used to create file handles.

serverport.usage: Port number used by the server

serverstatuscode.usage: Numerical representation of a statusfrom ther server

service.usage: Service in the generic sense, typically represents a windows service, network service identifier, or other service description.

sessionname.usage: Name used to identify a session

sessiontype.usage: Type of session referenced in the log

severity.usage: General purpose field used to capture severity level

severityvalue.usage: General purpose field used to capture numerical severity level

sha1.usage: computed SHA1 hash of an object

sha256.usage: computed SHA256 has of an object

sha512.usage: computed SHA512 has of an object

site.usage: General purpose field for representing a site, physical or logical

size.usage: General purpose field for representing the size of something, e.g. disk size=2TB

sizeinram.usage: Specific size of something, measured in bytes, in RAM

sizeondisk.usage: Specific size of something, measured in bytes, on Disk

slot.usage: used to capture a slot, typically referring to infrastructure equipment.

snort_alert.usage: In HIP events, the snort alert

source.usage: source referring to the source of the event log, e.g. httpd, auth, etc.

sourceclass.usage: Refered to a class in a program source code.

srccountry.usage: The full name of the source country, when orientation is known, used for geolocation

srccountrycode.usage: The source country code, when source/dest is known, used for geolocation

srchost.usage: hostname of the source machine, when direction is known and/or relevant, will typically resolve to srcip or srcipv6

srcmac.usage: MAC address of the source when direction is known

srcnatrule.usage: JunOS source address NAT flow rule name

srcserver.usage: IPv4 address of the source server in a DHCP connection

srczone.usage: Source zone, when direction is known and/or relevant, typically reserved for network or firewall events specifying a logical zone within the event

ssid.usage: Service identifier that uniquely names a wireless local area network (WLAN). Sometimes referred as a "network name"

ssl.usage: in bro logs, flag the connection if it was seen over ssl

starttime.usage: date/time that something first started, typically referring to connection events or events with a definitive start and end

starttimeutc.usage: UTC date/time that something first started, typically referring to connection events or events with a definitive start and end

static_indicators.usage: In HIP events, the static indicators

status.usage: The present status of something (on/off, enabled/disabled, 'File Format Error', etc) NOT to be confused with result.

status_changed_at_time.usage: The date/time when the status of something changed

statuscode.usage: Numerical representation of a status, typically used in network protocols like http status code 200,302,400's, etc.

statusmsg.usage: Status message, from Bro http log status_message field contains the status message returned by the server.

strings.usage: In Satori logs, the strings field

stringval.usage: Value of any arbitrary string of interest for parsing, typically reserved when the string is the "payload" of interest

subfiletype.usage: In Satori logs, the subfile type

subject.usage: subject, with respect to communications. Typically used in email, IM, etc.

submit_to_satori_at_time.usage: In HIP events, the date/time when it was submitted to satori

submittedAt.usage: The date/time when something is submitted

submitted_by.usage: In HIP events, the event was submitted by

submitted_by_name.usage: In HIP events, the field for submitted by name

suppressfor.usage: In Bro notice logs, the suppress_for field can be set if there is a natural suppression interval for the notice that may be different than the default value.

system.usage: a system, or overarching platform, eg. "e-commerce", or "payroll", not to be used as hostname

tags.usage: Tags, found in Bro http logs, identify a set of indicators of various attributes discovered and related to a particular request/response pair.

target.usage: The user or service/object that the action was performed on

targetdomain.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targethost.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targetip.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targetipv6.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targetlogonid.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targetusername.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

targetusersecurityid.usage: Typically oberved in host IDS/IPS, AV, and others when referencing a targeted system or user

task.usage: Any task name, typically found in windows event logs as task

tcp_details.usage: TCP related data from NX EC logs.

technique.usage: General purpose field for representing technique

threshold.usage: General purpose field for representing any type of interger based threshold

timedout.usage: In Bro logs, whether the file analysis timed out at least once for the file.

timezone.usage: Timezone, typically expressed in either an offset, e.g. -0500 or in a three letter timezone code, e.g. EST, GMT, etc

to.usage: General purpose field for representing to, with respect to origin. Typically used in email, IM, etc.

total_bytes.usage: in bro logs, total number of bytes that are supposed to comprise the full file

totalanswers.usage: The total number of resource records in a (DNS) reply message’s answer section.

totalpages.usage: Total number of pages, typically referencing print or copy jobs in windows logs

totalreplies.usage: The total number of resource records in a (DNS) reply message’s answer, authority, and additional sections.

transdstip.usage: Translated IPv4 address of the destination

transsrcip.usage: Translated IPv4 address of the source

trigger_details.usage: In HIP events, the field trigger details

truncationbit.usage: The Truncation bit specifies that the message was truncated.

ttl.usage: Time to Live measured in seconds

tty.usage: Physical or virtual terminal being used by a user

tunnel_type.usage: in bro logs, the type of tunnel

tunnelparents.usage: Tunnel parents, found in Bro conn logs, identifes a set of one or more encapsulation tunnel UID values for parent connections used over the lifetime of this inner connection.

type.usage: General purpose field for interger types, such as type {1,2,3,} etc

type_details.usage: Generic field to store details about specific protocol events from NX EC.

uid.usage: Used when a given user (i.e. joesample) also has a unique user ID or GUID (i.e. 9473), see also username

unparsed_version.usage: in bro logs, the full unparsed versions string found because the version parsing doesn't always work reliably in all cases and this acts as a fallback in the logs

url.usage: When necessary, the full URL including domain and URI fields.

useragent.usage: User Agent of an HTTP client

usercheck.usage: Used to describe the rule for user checking services in Checkpoint logs and other.

usercheckid.usage: The unique identifier for a user check record.

userchecklvl.usage: Defines the level of user checking set in Checkpoint logs & other

username.usage: any one specific username.  Typcially some form of identity object from an identity store.

usersecurityid.usage: Unique, immutable identifier of a Windows user.

uses_aslr.usage: in bro logs, true if file supports aslr

uses_code_integrity.usage: in bro logs, true if file enforces code integrity checks

uses_dep.usage: in bro logs, true if file supports dep

uses_seh.usage: in bro logs, true if file uses structured exception handling

uuid.usage: A universally unique identifier (UUID) is an identifier standard used in software construction

version.usage: used to futher specify the version of anything with a revision level, operating systems, applications, protocols, etc.

virus.usage: General purpose field for representing the vendor specified streetname for a virus.

vlanname.usage: Name used to identify a VLAN

volume.usage: a volume, typically a storage volume, see also disk

vt_first_seen.usage: General purpose field for date/time when virus total was first seen

vt_ratio.usage: General purpose field for virus total ratio

webclient.usage: User browser application within Checkpoint logs & other

webclienttype.usage: Secondary field tied to webclient. Populates when webclient is Other.

webserver.usage: Web server used when an http request is processed.

webservertype.usage: The webserver version when webserver field equals Other.

weight.usage: General purpose field for representing weight, literal or figurative

whitelist_info.usage: Whitelist info, the listing like grey etc

workstation.usage: workstation name, only used in cases where hostname is already used and workstation is explicitly declared

x509.usage: in bro logs, information about x509 certificates

xfwdforip.usage: X-Forwarded-For header value, comma+space delimited if more than one

yara_hits.usage: In HIP events, the description of yara hits

year.usage: General purpose field for year values

zone.usage: Any DNS zone when it can't be converted to a readable domain
